answers: Elements can be inserted into a link list at any point and does not need to be resized unlike an array needs to be.
Unlike arrays, linked lists can insert and delete without shifting data and change in size easily.
Array size is fixed,but Linked is not fixed.
You can insert into and delete items from a pointer-based linked list without shifting data.
Arrays must be of a defined size... elements can be added to a linked list w/o defining any size.

The principal benefit of a linked list over a conventional array is that the order of the linked items may be different from the order that the data items are stored in memory or on disk, allowing the list of items to be traversed in a different order. A linked list is a self-referential datatype because it contains a pointer or link to another datum of the same type. Linked lists permit insertion and removal of nodes at any point in the list in constant time
You can expand when you need it.  You do not have to predetermine the size.
Linked lists are able to grow and shrink in size as needed

There is no limit as to how many you create where an array can only hold a given amount of information.
Linked lists have constant time insertion and deletion
Linked lists can be grown dynamically, items don't require shifting, and they have a greater awesome factor than that of arrays.
Linked lists have an indefinite size. They can be added to and taken away from very easily with little difficulty in the shifting of data.
Nearly infinite size, limited only by system memory and also the ability to expand the size dynamically.
